title: Bilateral Mixed Hearing Loss with History of SSNHL and Chronic Otitis Media
chief_complaint: I've noticed my hearing has decreased in my left ear since my last test about a year ago. I also have constant ringing in both ears.

problem_summary.onset: Decreased hearing in left ear noted over the last year; Right ear hearing loss was sudden (SSNHL) in the past.
problem_summary.course: Right ear loss did not improve with prior intratympanic steroid injections. Left ear has recently worsened.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant bilateral tinnitus; history of chronic otitis media and Eustachian tube dysfunction.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Decreased ability to receive speech, particularly in the right ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitoring hearing status and managing chronic middle ear issues.

history.present_illness: Patient reports decreased hearing in the left ear since last test ~1 year ago. Reports constant bilateral tinnitus.
history.otologic_history: History of Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SSNHL) in the Right Ear (failed steroid treatment). History of chronic otitis media and Eustachian tube dysfunction bilaterally. History of bilateral PE tubes; tube still present in the Left Ear.
history.prior_management: Intratympanic dexamethasone injections for Right Ear SSNHL (unsuccessful). PE tubes bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right Ear: Mild mixed loss (250-500 Hz) sloping to severe mixed loss at 8000 Hz. Left Ear: Mild-to-moderate mixed loss (250-2000 Hz), rising to mild mixed (3000-4000 Hz), sloping to moderate-to-severe (6000-8000 Hz). Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally.

numeric_results.Masking_Note: Could not mask bone conduction thresholds at 1, 2, 3, and 4 kHz due to magnitude of hearing loss in non-test ear.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores in agreement with PTA bilaterally. Right ear shows moderate difficulty in speech recognition (62%). Left ear shows normal ability to recognize speech (96%) at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Abnormally large ear canal volumes bilaterally, consistent with perforation or patent PE tubes. Right ear shows excessive negative pressure despite large volume. Left ear is flat (Type B).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral mixed hearing loss. The right ear exhibits a moderate-to-severe mixed loss with reduced speech discrimination (62%), likely sequelae of prior SSNHL and chronic middle ear disease. The left ear shows a mild-to-moderate mixed loss with excellent speech discrimination (96%). Tympanometry reveals large ear canal volumes bilaterally, consistent with the history of PE tubes and tympanic membrane perforations.
counseling_points: Explain the 'mixed' nature of the hearing loss: a combination of permanent nerve damage (sensorineural) and mechanical issues (conductive/middle ear).
Discuss the status of the PE tubes/eardrums: The large volumes confirm the tube in the left ear is open or there is a perforation, and the right ear also shows signs of perforation/patency.
Emphasize water precautions: Keep ears dry to prevent infection due to open pathway to the middle ear.
Recommend a hearing aid evaluation, noting that the left ear is a good candidate due to high speech clarity scores.
Advise on hearing protection in noisy environments to preserve remaining hearing.
notes_for_actor: You have a long history of ear infections and tubes.
You are likely frustrated that your 'good ear' (the left one) is now getting worse.
You have constant ringing (tinnitus) in both ears which may be annoying or distracting.
